pydynaa.Entity

class pydynaa.core.Entity

Anything within the simulation that is capable of generating or responding to events.

The Entity class should be inherited from rather than instantiated directly.

If an Entity leaves scope in python it will be garbage collected (GC), i.e. freed from memory, similarly to any other python object. This will happen even if the entity is the source of events that still exist on the simulation timeline, as these only hold a weak reference to it. Events on the simulation timeline that were created by an Entity that has been freed from memory will no longer be triggered.

Notes

The Entity class uses the __cinit__ method to construct a new _CyEntity C++ object on the heap. Because __cinit__ is always called once, Entity can be safely subclassed – which is the intended usage. However, this python class should not be used to wrap existing _CyEntity objects using __new__, as the creation of a new C++ object cannot be avoided.

_dismiss(self, handler, Entity entity=None, EventType event_type=None, Event event=None, long event_id=Event.any_id, EventExpression expression=None)

Dismiss an event handler waiting for certain events to be triggered.

Parameters:

  • handler (EventHandler or ExpressionHandler) – The event or expression handler to be dismissed.

  • entity (Entity or None, optional) – Only events from this entity will match the filter.

  • event_type (EventType or None, optional) – Only events of the given event_type will match the filter.

  • event (Event or None, optional) – Only the specific event will match the filter.

  • event_id (int, optional) – Only the specific event (with given event id) will match the filter.

  • expression (ExpressionHandler or None, optional) – Event expression to wait on. If specified (not None) it overrides the other event related parameters (entity, event_type, event, event_id).

Notes

If an event is passed as parameter, its information overrides all other parameters. Other parameters are ignored.

Raises:

TypeError – If passed parameters are not of the expected type.

_schedule_after(self, double interval, EventType event_type)

Schedules an event of given event type to be triggered after a given interval – counting from the actual time.

Use this function to schedule an event after a certain delay counting from the current simulation time. The event triggered will be of the given event type.

Parameters:

  • interval (float) – The interval after which the event will be triggered.

  • event_type (EventType) – The type of the event to be scheduled.

Returns:

The scheduled event.

Return type:

Event

Raises:

  • TypeError – If a event_type is passed that is not an EventType. Or if interval is not of float type.

  • Exception – If interval is negative

_schedule_at(self, double instant, EventType event_type)

Schedules an event of a given event type to be triggered at a given future time

Use this function to schedule an event at a certain time instant in the future (ahead in the simulation time). The event triggered will be of the given event type.

Parameters:

  • instant (float) – The instant at which the event will be triggered.

  • event_type (EventType) – The type of the event to be scheduled.

Returns:

The scheduled event.

Return type:

Event

Raises:

  • TypeError – If event_type not an EventType. Or if instant is not of double type.

  • Exception – Or if instant is negative. Or if instant is past in the simulation time.

_schedule_now(self, EventType event_type)

Schedules an event of given type at the current simulation time (instantaneous)

Use this function to schedule immediately an event of given event type.

Parameters:

event_type (EventType) – The type of the event to be scheduled.

Returns:

The scheduled event.

Return type:

Event

Raises:

TypeError – If event_type is not an EventType.

_wait(self, handler, Entity entity=None, EventType event_type=None, Event event=None, long event_id=Event.any_id, bool once=False, EventExpression expression=None)

Waits continuously for certain events to be triggered.

Waits until a matching event is triggered. This wait remains until it is explicitly dismissed. Waiting for events requires declaring a matching (filter) criteria composed of a source, an event type, an event, or and event id; or a combination of those.

Parameters:

  • handler (EventHandler or ExpressionHandler) – The event or expression handler to be invoked when a triggered event matches the given filter.

  • entity (Entity or None, optional) – Only events from this entity will match the filter.

  • event_type (EventType or None, optional) – Only events of the given event_type will match the filter.

  • event (Event or None, optional) – Only the specific event will match the filter.

  • event_id (long, optional) – Only the specific event (with given event id) will match the filter. Event expression to wait on. If specified (not None) it overrides the other event related parameters (entity, event_type, event, event_id).

  • once (bool, optional) – Whether to only wait once.

  • expression (ExpressionHandler or None, optional) – Event expression to wait on. If specified (not None) it overrides the other event related parameters (entity, event_type, event, event_id).

Raises:

TypeError – If passed parameters are not of the expected type.

Notes

If a source is provided, only events coming from this source (entity) will match the filter and trigger the given event handler. If an event type is provided, only events of this given event type with match the filter and triffer the given event handler. If an event is provided, the filter expect until the specific given event is triggered and then the handler is dismissed – as if _waitOnce is called. If an event is provided, all other parameters (beside the event handler) are ignored. If and event_id is provided, only the event with the given event id matches the filter and triggers the given event handler. Combinations of those are possible, for example, if a source and an event type is provided, only events from this source and of the given event type will match the filter and trigger the event handler.

All future events matching the filter will cause an invocation of th event handler. To stop this behaviour, the event handler has to be dismissed.

_wait_once(self, handler, Entity entity=None, EventType event_type=None, Event event=None, long event_id=Event.any_id, EventExpression expression=None)

Waits once for a certain event to be triggered.

Waits exactly once until a matching event is triggered. Waiting for events requires declaring a matching (filter) criteria composed of a source, an event type, an event, or and event id; or a combination of those.

Parameters:

  • handler (EventHandler or ExpressionHandler) – The handler to be invoked when a triggered event or expression matches the given filter.

  • entity (Entity or None, optional) – Only events from this entity will match the filter.

  • event_type (EventType or None, optional) – Only events of the given event_type will match the filter.

  • event (Event or None, optional) – Only the specific event will match the filter.

  • event_id (long, optional) – Only the specific event (with given event id) will match the filter.

  • expression (ExpressionHandler or None, optional) – Event expression to wait on. If specified (not None) it overrides the other event related parameters (entity, event_type, event, event_id).

Raises:

TypeError – If passed parameters are not of the expected type.

Notes

If a source is provided, only events coming from this source (entity) will match the filter and trigger the given event handler. If an event type is provided, only events of this given event type with match the filter and triffer the given event handler. If an event is provided, the filter expect until the specific given event is triggered. If and event_id is provided, only the event with the given event id matches the filter and triggers the given event handler. Combinations of those are possible, for example, if a source and an event type is provided, only events from this source and of the given event type will match the filter and trigger the event handler.

Only the first event matching the filter will cause an invocation of th event handler. The following matches will not invoke the handler anymore.

remove(self)

Removes the entity from the simulation.

uid

returns a unique identifier for this entity in the simulation.

Each entity has a unique identifier in the simulation.

Type:

int

pydynaa.Event

class pydynaa.core.Event(*args, **kwargs)

An instance of time in the simulation with significance to a simulation entity.

Notes

Events are created by the simulation core and never directly by the user. For this reason, there is no initialization of an event. Events from the core can only be _wrapped_ for being accessed from python.

id

a unique identifier for the event during a simulation run.

Each event is uniquely identified by a long integer number in the simulation. This property can be used to retrieve this id.

Type:

int

source

the source entity that issued this event.

Each event is issued by one particular source. Sources of events are always entities. This property can be used to retrieve the source of this event.

Raises:

LookupError – If the source entity no longer exists i.e. has been garbage collected.

Type:

Entity

type

class:~pydynaa.core.EventType: the type of this event.

This property can be used to retrieve the type of this event.

Notes

This method returns a reference to an existing EventType instance (hopefully), and therefore memory should not be freed when the returned object is deleted. The call to __new__ bypasses __init__ so that __is_memory_allocated is False.

Type:

py

unschedule(self)

Unschedule this event from the simulation.

This event is removed from the simulation timeline, so that it is not issued anymore.

Notes

Unscheduling events that do are lon longer in the timeline, or that were already issued in the past yields no effect – no error (so no exception or error returned).

pydynaa.EventType

class pydynaa.core.EventType(str name, str description)

Type specification of an event.

As well as waiting for specific events, an Entity can wait for any event of a given type.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of the event type. Does not need to be unique, and should thereby not be used as a unique identifier.

  • description (str) – Description for the event type. Does not need to be unique, and should thereby not be used as a unique identifier.

Notes

The name and description of an event type are not unique identifiers. Use comparison operators to check equality.

Constructor creates a cDynAA equivalent event type and wraps it in a python object.

description

a short description of this event type.

Type:

str

id

a unique identifier for the event type.

Type:

int

name

the name of this event type.

Type:

str

pydynaa.EventExpression

class pydynaa.core.EventExpression(Entity source=None, EventType event_type=None, int event_id=Event.any_id)

Defines an expression over event conditions.

Event expressions allows the user to wait on combinations of events, such as an event (fromSourceA, any type, any id) & an event (fromSourceB, typeC, any id). Meaning that the expression will only be valid when both event conditions are met at least once, that is, events matching these conditions were issued at least once.

Very complex event expressions can be produced combining them in AND (&) and OR (|) operations.

Parameters:

  • source (Entity or None, optional) – The Entity that should be source of the event expression condition. If any_source or None then any source is matched.

  • event_type (EventType or None, optional) – The EventType that should be matched in the event expression condition. If any_type or None then any event type is matched.

  • event_id (int, optional) – The EventID to be matched in the event expression condition. If any_id or -1 then any event is matched.

Notes

The basic event expression – also called event condition or atomic event expression – is a a single condition (source, type, id) that has to be matched. In each part of the condition, wildcards any_source, any_type, or any_id can be used respectively.

Examples

Wait for either a rain or snow event type to occur (from any entities). Specifying a callback function to wait() is optional. Calling wait() will reset the expression value to False. The expression will become True once the event conditions are (again) matched.

weather_service = Entity()
gaia = Entity()
evtype_rain = EventType("Rain", "Rainy weather")
evtype_snow = EventType("Snow", "Snowy weather")

# Define a composite event expression:
evexpr_rain = EventExpression(source=gaia, event_type=evtype_rain)
evexpr_snow = EventExpression(source=gaia, event_type=evtype_snow)
evexpr_wetweather = evexpr_rain | evexpr_snow

def warning_callback(evexpr):
    condition = triggered_expr.triggered_events[-1].type.description
    print("Be careful: it's wet outside ({}).".format(condition))

warning_handler = ExpressionHandler(warning_callback)

# Wait on event expression using an expression handler:
weather_service._wait(warning_handler, expression=evexpr_wetweather)

# Schedule snow and run simulation:
gaia._schedule_now(evtype_snow)
SimulationEngine().run()

Event expressions can also be used directly at truth values i.e. in boolean expressions there is no calling their value attribute. For example:

if not evexpr_wetweather:
    print("It's okay to venture outside.")
atomic_id

int or None: The event ID of the atomic expression or None if not an atomic event expression.

atomic_source

Entity or None: The source entity of the atomic expression or None if not an atomic event expression.

atomic_type

EventType or None: The event type of the atomic expression or None if not an atomic event expression.

copy(self)

Copy this event expression.

This gives a unique copy of this event expression that is untriggered.

Returns:

A copy of the event expression.

Return type:

EventExpression

first_term

first term in this expression.

Type:

EventExpression

reprime(self)

Reset the event expression by setting all its atomic expressions to not triggered.

second_term

second term in this expression.

Type:

EventExpression

triggered_events

The events that caused this expression to trigger.

The events are sorted by the order in which they occured. If this is an atomic expression then the list will contain maximally one event.

Returns:

Triggering events sorted by occurance, or an empty list if the expression has not yet been triggered.

Return type:

list of Event

triggered_time

The time at which this event expression triggered, if applicable.

Returns:

Return type:

float or None

type

type of event expression.

Type:

{self.ATOMIC, self.AND, self.OR}

value

the current logical value of this expression in the simulation.

Type:

bool

wait(self, callback=None, int priority=_DEFAULT_PRIORITY_LEVEL_EventHandler)

pydynaa.EventHandler

class pydynaa.core.EventHandler

Handles an event for an Entity using a callback function.

An EventHandler must be specified to the Entity wait() and wait_once() methods for an event.

Parameters:

  • callback_function (function) – Callback function.

  • identifier (str or “”, optional) – Identifier for event handler.

  • safe_guards (list of Entity, optional) – A list of Entities to be used as safe guards of this event handler.

  • priority (int) – Priority of this event handler.

default_priority

Default priority level for event handlers.

Type:

int

highest_priority

The highest priority level for event handlers.

Type:

int

lowest_priority

The lowest priority level for event handlers.

Type:

int

Notes

One can pass python entities (derived from Entity) as safe guards to a callback. The existence of the safe guards will be checked before invoking the callback, that is the callback will not be invoked if the any of the safe guard entities do not exist anymore.

When creating a callback_function using a _closure_ beware of late-binding. For example, consider the case of creating callback functions in a loop with the help of lambda functions:

for i in range(5):
    handlers.append(EventHandler(lambda event: print(i)))

The effect of late binding is that each callback will print _i=5_. One way to counter-act late binding a default argument can be used to bind immediately:

for i in range(5):
    handlers.append(EventHandler(lambda event, i=i: print(i)))

The EventHandler class uses the __cinit__ method to construct a new C++ _EventHandler C++ object on the heap. Because __cinit__ is always called once, EventHandler can be safely subclassed. However, this python class should no be used to wrap existing C++ _EventHandler objects using __new__, as the creation of a new C++ object cannot be avoided.

Examples

def callbackA(event):
    print("Source UID".format(event.source.uid))

def callbackB(time):
    print("Event occured at {}".format(time))

class CB(Entity):
    def callbackAsMethod(event):
        print("This is a method used as callback. Use CB as safe guard")

handlerA = EventHandler(callbackA)
handlerB = EventHandler(lambda event: callbackB(6))
entity = CB()
# sets entity as a safe guard.  callback is only invoked if entity still exists.
handlerC = EventHandler(lambda event: entity.callbackAsMethod(event), [entity])
handle(self, Event ev)

Handle an event.

Parameters:

ev (Event) – Event to handle.

identifier

identifier of event handler.

Type:

str

priority

priority level of this event handler.

Type:

int

pydynaa.ExpressionHandler

class pydynaa.core.ExpressionHandler

Handles an event expression for an Entity using a callback function.

An ExpressionHandler must be specified to the Entity wait() and wait_once() methods.

Parameters:

  • callback_function (function(EventExpression) or None) – Callback function taking event expression as argument, or None.

  • identifier (str, optional) – Identifier for expression handler.

  • safe_guards (list of Entity, optional) – A list of Entities to be used as safe guards of this expression handler.

  • priority (int) – Priority of this expression handler.

default_priority

Default priority level for expression handlers.

Type:

int

highest_priority

The highest priority level for expression handlers.

Type:

int

lowest_priority

The lowest priority level for expression handlers.

Type:

int

Notes

See also the notes for EventHandler.

The ExpressionHandler class uses the __cinit__ method to construct a new C++ _ExpressionHandler C++ object on the heap. Because __cinit__ is always called once, ExpressionHandler can be safely subclassed. However, this python class should no be used to wrap existing C++ _ExpressionHandler objects using __new__, as the creation of a new C++ object cannot be avoided.

handle(self, eventExpr)

Handle an event or event expression.

Parameters:

eventExpr (EventExpression or Event) – Event expression or event to handle with callback function.

identifier

identifier of event handler.

Type:

str

priority

priority level of this event handler.

Type:

int

pydynaa.SimulationEngine

class pydynaa.core.SimulationEngine

The engine of the simulation.

Used to run, stop and reset discrete event simulations.

There is only one single (singleton) simulation engine per python session.

This simulation engine instance is the same for any python SimulationEngine instance that is created. This behavior is ensured during initialization.

Notes

Only one instance can be active per Python interpreter.

current_time

return the current time in the simulation.

Type:

float

get_diagnostic_info(self)

dict: diagnostic info.

get_expression_handlers(self, EventExpression expression)

Retrieve list of registered expression handlers for an event expression.

Parameters:

expression (EventExpression) – Event expression to inspect for registered expression handlers.

Returns:

List of tuples of expression handler and a boolean indicating if expression is single shot (once).

Return type:

list of (ExpressionHandler, bool)

num_events

number of events currently on the simulation timeline.

Type:

int

num_handlers

number of event handlers currently registered in the simulation.

Type:

int

num_instants

number of time instants currently on the simulation timeline.

Type:

int

reset(self)

Reset the simulation by clearing all scheduled events and setting time to 0.

Notes

After stop(), if the simulation is not reset, invoking run() will resume the simulation from the moment it stopped.

After reset, the simulation time is sent back to time zero, all events are eliminated from the timeline, and existing entities are disposed. It brings the simulator to an initial state without any simulation entities in it.

run(self, end_time=None)

Run the simulation.

Parameters:

end_time (float or None, optional) – Time up to which to run the simulation, not including this instant itself. In other words, events scheduled at end_time will not be issued. If end_time is None, simulation will run until there are no more events in the timeline.

Notes

It can be the case that there will always be a new event in the timeline. In this case, not passing an end_time to the run may cause a never ending simulation.

Examples

sim_engine = SimulationEngine()
sim_engine.run(10.)  # runs simulation up to simulation time 10
# State of the simulation is now at time 10

# Resumes the simulation and stops only when there are no further events
# in the timeline:
sim_engine.run()
state

return the current state of the simulation. 0 = idle, 1 = running, 2 = stopped.

Type:

float

stop(self)

Permanently stop the simulation.

Simulation must be reset in order to run again from the beginning.

Notes

Stops the simulation means the actual time of the simulation is frozen and further (future) events are not thrown. No further activation of any entity in the simulation.
